text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English
speaker: Sophie

text: from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Sophie.
And I'm Neil. Oh, hang on. I've just got a new tweet here.
Oh, listen to this. Hi, Neil, about what you said the other day.
I... Oh, um...
This is from a friend who doesn't realise that regular tweets are in the public domain
and that anyone in the world could read them if they wanted to.
I need to give her some lessons in cool. She just doesn't get it.
Well, Mr Cool, I don't get Twitter either – which means I don't understand why people like it.
speaker: get

text: Why do you want to put tweets out there for everyone to read?
You'd love it if you tried it, Sophie.
I'm not so sure, Neil. Anyway, the subject of today's show is online identity.
speaker: Sophie

text: There are lots of social media platforms out there,
Facebook, Twitter, WhatsApp, Instagram, and they're all different.
And the question is, do we use different identities when we are using different digital spaces?
And what's all this tweeting, posting and hashtagging doing to our language and our psyche?
And psyche means mind. Well, it's messed with my mind. I'm a total addict.
I check my accounts as soon as I get up in the morning.
And sometimes in the night, if I wake up, I couldn't get through the day without it.
Well, I'm the opposite – I'm totally unaddicted
speaker: Sophie

text: And therefore, don't need to worry about my psyche.
Now, before we explore this further, let's have today's quiz question.
Okay, here's one for you, Sophie. Can you tell me how many social media accounts the average person has?
Is it A, 3, B, 5 or C, 8?
speaker: tribe

text: I'll say 3. That sounds like 3 too many to me.
Okay, well, we'll find out if you've got the answer right later on in the show.
I've got 3, 5. No, hang on, hang on. I've got 6.
While you add up all your accounts, Neil, let's listen to Dr Alex Kutowski,
broadcaster, journalist, and social psychologist.
speaker: Neil

text: She's talking about the language we use to present ourselves online.
Online we have this extraordinary opportunity to explore different aspects of ourselves
speaker: Dr Aleks Krotoski, broadcaster, journalist and social psychologist

text: through primarily text-based communication by manipulating language and becoming wordsmests ourselves.
So, for example, your Twitter handle will have a U that is probably different from a U that you share,
if, say, for example, you have a Facebook account, or is different from a U that you would share
if you're on a particular forum of something that you like, some music that you like, or food
that you like, or whatever it is. So, we are wordsmests with handles.
What does that mean? A wordsmith is someone who is skilled at using words,
and a handle means a name. What's your Twitter handle then?
speaker: wordsmithhandle

text: Well, you'll need to get a Twitter account to find out. But I have other handles for other social media.
speaker: Neil

text: So, there are lots of U's out there, Neil?
Yes. For example, I think I'm cooler on Twitter than on Facebook. I talk more, you know,
speaker: Neil

text: street. Check out my new crepes. They're banging.
Yo, they're well-sick. Streets, by the way, refers to the language that goes with street,
or urban culture, where things like skateboarding and hip-hop are popular.
And I think crepes are trainers. Am I right, bruv?
Yes, Sophie. I didn't know you could talk street!
speaker: Neil

text: I have identities that you know nothing about, Neil.
But getting back to Twitter and how big an audience there is,
doesn't that huge audience worry you, Neil? Aren't you scared of making a huge blooper online
and becoming a laughing stock? Okay, blooper means an embarrassing mistake,
and being a laughing stock means looking very silly when you're trying to be serious.
Well, Sophie, I'm quite careful about how I manage my online identity.
speaker: bloopera laughing stock

text: I take time to craft my words, just like I craft them for this show.
Really? So no bloopers on this show, then? I seem to remember one or two.
Well, let's move on now and listen to Dr Alex Kutowski again,
talking about what motivates us to put our thoughts and ideas out there online.
It's allowing us a platform for a potential audience that is massive,
speaker: Dr Aleks Krotoski, broadcaster, journalist and social psychologist

text: Absolutely huge. So yeah, there is a lot of look at me, look at me online.
But that's, I think, because we're trying to reach out to as much of the audience,
we're trying to get as much attention as we possibly can in order to get that tribe.
And also, in order to basically reach out and tell people, hey, we're around.
It's like having a telephone on all the time. Hey, chat to me. I'm here.
Anybody want to hang out? It's a big social playground.
Alex Kutowski says, we're all show-offs who want attention.
Am I a show-off, Sophie? Yes, you are, Neil. Though Alex says it isn't just about showing off,
it's also about connecting with people in our tribe or social group.
But that tribe can be enormous because people are reading posts globally,
not just in your own town or even your own country.
Hashtag scary thought. Now, I think it's time for the answer to today's quiz question.
I asked, how many social media accounts does the average person have? Is it a,
3, B, 5 or C, 8? I said B, 3.
And that is not the right answer. So, for the average person, has five social media accounts and spends
around one hour and 40 minutes browsing these networks every day,
accounting for 28% of the total time spent on the internet.
speaker: Sophie

text: Now, here are the words we heard today. Get something.
Psychie.
wordsmith
speaker: Neil

text: handle
speaker: Neil

text: Street.
blooper
speaker: Neil

text: Laughing stock.
tribe
speaker: Neil

text: And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English.
Don't forget to join us again soon.
And remember, you can tweet us at BBCLE.
Bye-bye. Bye-bye.
6 Minute English from the BBC.
